perturbation.original_text: Licensor grants to Rogers the non-exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the "Territory") all entertainment programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, "Licensed Programs") to residential subscribers of Rogers' digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand ("VOD") basis. For clarity, the VOD service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the "ROD Service".
perturbation.changed_text: Licensor grants to Rogers the non-exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the "Territory") all entertainment programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, "Licensed Programs") to residential subscribers of Rogers' digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand ("VOD") basis. For clarity, the VOD service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the "ROD Service", but only for subscribers with active Rogers accounts for at least 6 months.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction by adding a qualification to the definition of "ROD Service". The original definition simply refers to the VOD service provided to subscribers, but the modified definition restricts it to subscribers with accounts active for at least six months. This creates uncertainty as to which subscribers are actually eligible for the ROD service under this agreement.

perturbation.original_text: During the Term, Rogers shall have the non-exclusive right to distribute and exhibit each Licensed Program on a VOD basis for a period of ninety (90) consecutive days, or such longer period as may be agreed to by Rogers and Licensor (the "License Period").
perturbation.changed_text: During the Term, Rogers shall have the non-exclusive right to distribute and exhibit each Licensed Program on a VOD basis for a period of ninety (90) consecutive days from the first date the content is made available, or such longer period as may be dictated by Licensor based on market conditions (the "License Period").
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a conflicting definition of the License Period. Originally, it was a fixed 90-day period or a period agreed upon by both parties. Now, it could also be determined by Licensor based on market conditions, creating ambiguity and potentially allowing the Licensor to unilaterally alter the License Period. This could lead to disputes over the length of time Rogers is allowed to exhibit the Licensed Programs.

perturbation.original_text: Any Notice given pursuant to this Agreement shall make specific reference to this Agreement. Any Notice so given shall be deemed to have been received on the date on which it was delivered in person, or transmitted, if delivered or transmitted on a day, other than a Saturday, on which the Toronto-Dominion Bank in Toronto is open for business (a "Business Day") during normal business hours of the recipient and, if not so delivered or transmitted, on the next Business Day or, if sent by registered mail, on the fifth (5t h) Business Day thereafter; provided, however, that either party may change its address and/or facsimile number for purposes of receipt of any such communication by giving ten (10) days prior written notice of such change to the other party in the manner prescribed above.
perturbation.changed_text: Any Notice given pursuant to this Agreement shall make specific reference to this Agreement. Any Notice so given shall be deemed to have been received immediately upon sending, regardless of the method, provided that the sender has proof of transmission or delivery. However, for critical legal notices pertaining to termination or breach of contract, receipt will only be considered valid if acknowledged in writing by the receiving party within 7 business days.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates a conflict regarding when a notice is considered 'received'. The original text specifies conditions based on delivery method and Business Days. The modified text introduces a new, contradictory rule: immediate receipt upon sending with proof, unless it's a critical legal notice, which requires written acknowledgment within 7 days. This makes it unclear when notice is effective, especially for routine communication versus critical legal matters, potentially impacting timelines and obligations under the contract.
